title: Penetrating Thoracic Trauma with Hemothorax
diagnosis_topic: Gunshot wound causing massive hemothorax and potential cardiac injury
setup_script: A 29-year-old man presents with a single gunshot wound to the left posterior chest. He is short of breath and coughing up blood. He has no past medical history.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses airway and breathing
dynamic_flow.reply: Airway patent, but breath sounds decreased on the left side with dullness to percussion.
BP 95/55 mmHg, HR 125 bpm, RR 28/min, SpO2 90% on non-rebreather mask.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident places large-bore chest tube on the left
dynamic_flow.reply: 1.5 L of blood immediately returns followed by continuous output > 200 mL/hr.
Left hemothorax with mediastinal shift; tube position confirmed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates transfusion and obtains type and cross
If resident consults trauma surgery and cardiothoracic surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Prepare for emergent thoracotomy due to massive chest tube output.
Patient becomes hypotensive and suffers cardiac arrest.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about indication for thoracotomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Initial chest tube output > 1500 mL or > 200 mL/hr suggests ongoing arterial bleeding.
Concern for pulmonary and possibly cardiac injury; plan clamshell or posterolateral thoracotomy.
Administer IV analgesia and consider intubation for airway protection.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about postoperative complications
dynamic_flow.reply: Risk of retained hemothorax, empyema, ARDS; requires monitoring.
Use cell saver if available to reinfuse shed blood.

critical_decision_points: Management of airway, breathing and circulation in penetrating chest trauma
Recognition of massive hemothorax and indications for thoracotomy
Timely chest tube placement and monitoring of output
Activation of operative team without unnecessary delay
